Description.val:
Procurement of Valve Regulated Lead Acid (VRLA) batteries and installation of Ship Alteration (ShipAlt) to modify submarines from use of legacy flooded battery (no longer in production at former sole source manufacturer) to new design VRLA battery.  Installation of the VRLA battery includes installation of a new Automatic Battery Monitoring system (ABMS) as part of the ShipAlt.  This program procures and installs initial and replacement VRLA batteries for all classes of submarines (LOS ANGELES, SEAWOLF, OHIO SSBN/SSGNs and VIRGINIA).  Batteries have a finite life and are consumables; this budget procures replacement VRLA batteries throughout the submarine service life on a notional 4 to 5 year replacement cycle.  
Battery operation and capacity is critical.  Without acceptable battery capacity submarines cannot deploy effectively reducing the submarine force at a time when Strategic requirements, force protection and intelligence gathering capabilities are in high demand by combatant commanders.  Beginning in FY19, program requirements were increased to provide needed critical support to operational submarines.  These are funded via HM830 and include:
Battery Installation Test Equipment/Fixtures:  Procures battery charging and test equipment to support the testing, balancing, and charging of Submarine Batteries at Puget Sound Naval Shipyard (PSNSY).  This replaces the current PSNS Battery Shop 1,500 Amperes(AMP) Motor Generator with a 5,000 AMP solid state battery charger and other improvements required to conduct pre installation battery testing and troubleshooting prior to installation on SSBN/SSGNs. 
Submarine Battery Evaluation Center (SUBBEC):  Procures needed equipment and test stands for a full battery test station at NSWC Crane to test a full submarine battery (250+ cells).  This is vitally needed to help solve the battery life issues being experienced in the fleet.  The proposed system would allow 24/7 unmanned testing and evaluation within the existing submarine battery test activity at NSWC Crane.  Current capability must be constantly manned and monitored and only allows for testing of a small quantity of cells which does not provide a completely accurate representation of submarine battery operating profile or battery reaction to changes in profiles due to inherent in-balance in the strings of cells as installed on a submarine.
Automated Battery Monitoring System (ABMS) Tech Refresh: Upgrades the currently fielded ABMS system that was developed in 2002 and is suffering from continued obsolescence issues which are directly impacting the fleet operations.  Upgrades will be performed by NSWC Crane Power and Energy Division.  The Power and Energy Division has one of the only DoD owned and operated circuit board production lines with reverse engineering and technical capabilities required to perform this Tech Refresh.

HM002 LOS ANGELES SSN, HM008 OHIO Class SSBN/SSGN, HM009 SEAWOLF Class SSN, and HM010 VIRGINIA Class SSN:  Procures replacement low maintenance sealed lead acid batteries for all submarines.  This replaces flooded battery technology for which the industrial base ceased manufacture and support of in 2005.  OHIO Class SSBN/SSGN replacements include handling and shipping trays to speed change-out during short refit periods.  Funds are provided based on a reduced 4 to 5 year planned replacement cycle. 

HM830 Production Engineering:  Naval Surface Warfare Center (NSWC) Crane, as the designated procurement activity and In-Service Engineering Agent (ISEA) monitors battery performance and schedules replacements with the fleet.  NSWC Crane is tasked with leading a Government & Industry Root Cause Analysis (RCA) team to identify and address battery performance issues and provide corrective actions to operational submarines.  NSWC Crane conducts qualification testing of delivered VRLA and analysis of poor performing VRLA cells returned from operational submarines which has proven very beneficial to the Navy in detecting battery deficiencies before installation, thus alleviating critical emergent fleet impact and assisting in identifying failure modes to improve long term performance.  Funding provided to Puget Sound and Portsmouth Naval Shipyards include responsibilities for the VRLA and flooded battery inventory management, maintenance and storage, SHIPALT support, and Alteration Installation Team (AIT) management.  Also, Planning Yard and Lead Yard Services are funded through this line.  ***Starting in FY19 Puget Sound and FY20 Portsmouth Naval Shipyard (PNSY) Battery Teams originally funded in within the battery installation costs will be funded in this line.  This will enable the battery warehouse, battery shops and the subject matter experts to complete critical diagnostics, balancing, boosting, cabinets, shipping crates, testing and reporting, etc. ***

HM5IN Procurement for Install/Installation under $10M:  Procurement of Valve Regulated Lead Acid (VRLA) batteries and install of the ShipAlt to modify submarines from use of legacy flooded batteries for the LOS ANGELES, OHIO, SEAWOLF and VIRGINIA Class Submarines.   Installation unit costs vary due to the availability types, location of installation and submarine type.  All initial procurements and installations for the OHIO and SEAWOLF Class are complete.  The final installation on the LOS ANGELES Class SSN 765 has moved ahead to FY19 from FY20.

Justification.val:
The increased funding FY 2019 through FY 2021 provides for Main Storage Batteries and a series of critical three year projects for Submarine Battery program that includes the Battery Installation Test Equipment/Fixtures, the Submarine Battery Evaluation Center and the Automated Battery Monitoring System.  Details on these projects are included in the description above.

FY18 control increased $5M in FY18 by Congressional Add for shortfall in battery supply due to the average battery life decreasing from 5 yrs. to 4 yrs. for some batteries.  FY18 actuals and out year projections have changed due to costs reflected in the FY18 new IDIQ contract award.  Individual battery lines in HM002, HM008, HM009 and HM010 now reflect costs related to the individual battery only.  Trays are on a separate line.

The planned FY19 installation of the VRLA battery change out has moved up from FY20 to FY19.

Name.val: 1) HM002 - LOS ANGELES Class Main Storage Battery

Name.@footnote: 1.1  The Battery set price discontinuities within FY18 and moving forward to FY19 and beyond are attributable to  *the new IDIQ contract award in 2018*.  Estimated prices for FY19-FY24 are based on individual battery set procurements under the new contract.  The contract strategy is based on cell quantities and there is opportunity for price reductions per battery if purchased in bulk quantities.  FY18 shows actuals including new contract pricing.  FY19-FY24 are projected VRLA battery unit costs and reflect the cost in the existing commercial dual vendor contract.  The costs vary by procurement FY, vendor, procurement quantity, boosting intervals, packaging and storage duration.  Starting this PB20 budget trays are listed on a separate line.
Name.val: 1.1) LA VRLA Battery Storage Boosting Packaging

Name.@footnote: 2.2 New Line.  Starting in FY18, trays costs are shown separate from the battery costs.

Name.val: 2) HM008 - OHIO Class Main Storage Battery
2.1) OH VRLA Battery Storage Boosting Packaging
3) HM009 - SEAWOLF Class Main Storage Battery
3.1) SW VRLA Battery Storage Boosting Packaging
4) HM010 - VIRGINIA Class Main Storage Battery
4.1) VA VRLA  Battery Storage Boosting Packaging
5) HM830 - Production Engineering / Test Equipment/ SUBEC / ABMS Tech Refresh

Name.@footnote: 5.2 Battery Installation Test Equipment/Fixtures FY19 new start.  Funding is provided for the purchase of battery charging equipment to support the testing, balancing, and charging of Submarine Batteries.  For this equipment will replace the Puget Sound NSY Battery Shop 1500 AMP Motor Generator with 5,000A AMP solid state battery charger in to Bldg. 978. Improvements are required to conduct pre installation battery testing and troubleshooting.

5.3 Submarine Battery Evaluation Center (SUBBEC) FY19 new start funding is provided for the full string battery test station (SUBBEC).  The Submarine Battery Evaluation Center tests multiple battery string configurations which mirror specific submarine class installations.  FY19 - FY21 funding encompasses the design phase, material procurement, performance evaluation, lab upgrades, installation and testing.

5.4 FY19 new start provides funding for ABMS Tech Refresh that will be performed by NSWC Crane Power and Energy Division.  The current plan is for material and Installation of the tech refresh beginning in Aug 2019.  The installation is on ABMS on all Class VRLA Battery modified submarines and will continue through FY21.

Name.val: 6) HM5IN Procurement for Install / Installation under $10M

Name.@footnote: The installation of the SSN 765 was originally scheduled for FY20 and has moved forward to FY19 due to battery performance issues.
Name.val: 6.1) LA Class Procurement for Install/ Installation under $10M
6.2) OH Class Procurement for Install/Installation under $10M
